sentences.original: kîtahtawê ôki ayîsiyiniwak êh-mihcêticik, mîkiwâhpah êh-mihcêtihkih, kîtahtawê pêyak awa êh-okimâwit nmoy âwiyah owîkimâkanah.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê ôki ayîsiyiniwak ê-mihcêticik mîkiwâhpa ê-mihcêtihki kîtahtawê pêyak awa ê-okimâwit namôya awiya owîkimâkana
sentences.english: Once upon a time, in a place where there were many people and many tents, one of the chiefs had no wife.
[He was very good-looking.]

sentences.original: kotak okimâw nîso ayâwêw iskwêwah owîkimâkanah; êkosi pêyak miyosiw aw ôskinîkiskwêw.
sentences.text: kotak okimâw nîso ayâwêw iskwêwa owîkimâkana êkosi pêyak miyosiw awa oskinîkiskwêw
sentences.english: Another chief had two wives; one of them was a beautiful young woman.

sentences.original: awa kâ-môsâpêwit okimâw kimotamawêw ôh ôkimâwa owîkimâkaniyiwa;
sentences.text: awa kâ-môsâpêwit okimâw kimotamawêw ôhi okimâwa owîkimâkaniyiwa
sentences.english: The chief who was unmarried abducted this wife of the other chief's;
he could not find his wife.
Although he looked for her, he could not find her.

sentences.original: aw ôkimâw, iyâta-wistah-ntonawâci, âhci kâtêw, ôh ôskinîkiskwêwa êh-kâtât.
sentences.text: awa okimâw iyâta-wîsta-nitonawâci âhci kâtêw ôhi oskinîkiskwêwa ê-kâtât
sentences.english: The other chief, although he too looked for her, merely changed her hiding-place, for he was keeping the young woman in hiding.

sentences.original: têkohtêcih mîkiwâhpah, nista namoya nimiskawâw, itwêw.
sentences.english: When he came back to the tents, “I, too, cannot find her,” he would say.

sentences.original: piyisk ômis îtêyihtam aw ôkimâw : âh, nika-ntopayin; iyahciyiniwak nka-ntonawâwak, itêyihtam;
sentences.text: piyisk ômisi itêyihtam awa okimâw itêyihtam
sentences.english: At last this chief thought, “I shall go on the war-path; I shall look for Blackfoot,” he thought;

sentences.original: ôki kotakak oskinîkiwak kâ-nâpêhkâsocik nka-wîcêwâwak, itêyihtam aw ôkimâw;
sentences.english: “I shall take with me some of these young men who are braves,” thought this chief;
“I shall go away for a long time; for a year I shall go away.

sentences.original: êkosi nka-kîsig-ayâwâw aw îskwêw kâ-kimotiyân, itêyihtam.
sentences.english: In this way I shall be able to have the woman I have stolen,” he thought.

sentences.original: piyisk ntomêw oskinîkiwah, ê-wîhtamawât ê-wîh-ntopayit, iyahciyiniwah ê-wîh-ntonawât.
sentences.text: piyisk nitomêw oskinîkiwa ê-wîhtamawât ê-wî-nitopayit ayahciyiniwa ê-wî-nitonawât
sentences.english: At last he called a young man and told him that he was going on the war-path, to look for Blackfoot.

sentences.original: ôhi mâna êh-wîcêwât pêyak oskinîkiwa, nikwêmê, êh-itâhkômât, wîhtamawêw.
sentences.text: ôhi mâna ê-wîcêwât pêyak oskinîkiwa ê-itâhkômât wîhtamawêw
sentences.english: A certain young man with whom he used to go about, whom he called “my brother-in-arms” by way of relationship, to him he told his plan.

sentences.original: hâw, k-ôh-ntopayiyahk, kisîmak âtiht ta-wîhtamawacik âskaw; namoya ka-mihcêtiyahk, itêw.
sentences.english: “Now, I am calling you that you may here and there tell some of your juniors that we are going on the war-path; it is not my plan that we be many,” he told him.
“Yes,” said he.

sentences.original: mâka pitah wâskâhikanihk k-êtohtânânaw, kik-âtâwêyahk môsw-asiniyah êkwah kaskitêw êkwah ayôwinisah, êkâ kit-êsi-nôhtêpayiyahk kêkway, pêyak askiy ka-kakw-âyâyahk, itêw.
sentences.english: “But first we shall go to the fort, to buy bullets and powder and clothes, so that we may not run short of anything, as we plan to stay a year,” he told him.
“Yes.”
“Tomorrow we shall go to the trading-post,” he told him.

sentences.original: tâpwê êh-nâ-nipâwiht, ntawâpamêw ôh ôskinîkiskwêwa, ê-ntawi-wîhtamawât ôma êh-itêyihtahk.
sentences.text: tâpwê ê-nâ-nipâwiht nitawâpamêw ôhi oskinîkiskwêwa ê-nitawi-wîhtamawât ôma ê-itêyihtahk
sentences.english: Accordingly, when all the people were asleep, he went to see that young woman, to tell her of this which he had planned.

sentences.original: tâpwê êh-wâpahk mâhiskamok, êh-atâwêt môsw-asiniyah êkwah kaskitêw, ayôwinisah, minah mihkwêkin, kaskitêwêkin.
sentences.text: tâpwê ê-wâpahk mâhiskamok ê-atâwêt môsw-asiniya êkwa kaskitêw ayiwinisa mîna mihkwêkin kaskitêwêkin
sentences.english: Then,  on the next day, they went to the trading-post and he bought bullets and powder, and clothing, and red flannel cloth and black broadcloth.
Then he went home.

sentences.original: êh-takosihkik wîkiwâhk, ntomêw okimâw, ômisi êh-itât : aw, ôkimâtik, wâpahkih pita nka-ntonawâwak mostoswak, tântê ihtâtwâwi, êkota tây-ispiciyêk, itêw otînîmah;
sentences.text: ê-takosihkik wîkiwâhk nitomêw okimâw ômisi ê-itât itêw otiyinîma
sentences.english: When they arrived at the camp, he called the chiefs, and said to them, “Well now, Chiefs, tomorrow I shall go look for buffalo, so that you may move camp to wherever they are,” he told the chiefs;
“I mean to roam about,” he told them.
“So be it!”
“That is why I have called you.
I shall stay out two nights,” he told them.
“So be it!” they said.

sentences.original: tâpwê ,- êh-nîpihk ômah ,- kâ-wîh-sipwêhtêt, ê-kâh-kawisimôwiht, wiyâhpitêw nîso otêmah.
sentences.text: tâpwê ê-nîpihk ôma kâ-wî-sipwêhtêt ê-kâh-kawisimôwiht wiyahpitêw nîso otêma
sentences.english: And so, - this was in summer-time, - when he was ready to set out, when all the people had gone to bed, he saddled two of his horses.

sentences.original: êkosi êh-sipwêhtêt, ê-sipwêhtahât ôh îskwêwah, wâhyaw êh-tohtahât, itêh ta-k-îsi-sipwêhtêt.
sentences.text: êkosi ê-sipwêhtêt ê-sipwêhtahât ôhi iskwêwa wâhyaw ê-itohtahât itê ta-kî-isi-sipwêhtêt
sentences.english: Then he set out, taking that woman away with him, leading her far off in the direction which he was going to take.

sentences.original: tâpwê wâhyaw êh-ayât, ê-pasâhcâyik, ê-sakâyik, môhkiciwanipêk êh-ayâyik, mostoswah nipahêw pêyak, êkotah êh-nakatât ôh îskwêwah wiyâsah mîna.
sentences.text: tâpwê wâhyaw ê-ayât ê-pasahcâyik ê-sakâyik môhkiciwanipêk ê-ayâyik mostoswa nipahêw pêyak êkota ê-nakatât ôhi iskwêwa wiyâsa mîna
sentences.english: Then, when he was far away, in a wooded ravine where there was a spring, he killed a buffalo, and there he left that woman with the meat.

sentences.original: hâw osîhtâh kâhkêwakwah, itêw ôh îskwêwah, êh-kîwêt;
sentences.english: “Now then, prepare dried meats,” he told her, as he left for home;
“Do not ever go out into the open,” he told her;
“And do not feel lonely; I shall come here,” he told her.
Then he went home.
As he had said, after two nights he arrived in camp.
“Move your camp this way, toward the north.

sentences.original: ôtê wiya k-êtohtêyân nimitâw nama kêkway mostoswak, itêw.
sentences.english: Over this way where I have been, toward the south, there are no buffalo,” he told them.
Then at nightfall they set out.
They were thirty in number.
They took much baggage with them.
Once they camped before they got there;

sentences.original: mîna êh-wâpahk, êh-âpihtâ-kîsikâyik, k-otihtahkik ôh îtah iskwêwah kâ-kîh-nakatât.
sentences.text: mîna ê-wâpahk ê-âpihtâ-kîsikâyik kâ-otihtahkik ôhi ita iskwêwa kâ-kî-nakatât
sentences.english: on the next day, at noon, they came to where he had hidden the woman.
He stopped in his course.
“My brother-in-arms, go on ahead.
At yonder hill wait for me.

sentences.original: pita oma kâ-sakâk nika-kîskatahên misâskwatwah nîso, t-ôh-kanâcihtâyân nipâskisikan, itwêw.
sentences.english: I mean to stop and cut two saskatoon sticks in this grove, to clean my gun,” he said.

sentences.original: êkos ê-âti-sipwêhtêt, ê-pinasiwêt, sakâhk otihtêw ôhi kâ-kîh-kâtât iskwêwa.
sentences.text: êkosi ê-ati-sipwêhtêt ê-pinasiwêt sakâhk otihtêw ôhi kâ-kî-kâtât iskwêwa
sentences.english: So off he went, down into the gully, and to the woman he had hidden.
“I was just beginning to feel lonely,” she said.
So then he out the saskatoon sticks there.
“Make ready,” he told her;
“Over yonder the young men are on the march.”
Then they went off.
When they came into view, they saw the others there on the hilltop, smoking.

sentences.original: êkwah ôki oskinîkiwak êh-pê-sâkêwêyit êh-wâpamâcik, awiyah awa pê-wîcêwêw, itêwak otôkimâmiwâwa.
sentences.text: êkwa ôki oskinîkiwak ê-pê-sâkêwêyit ê-wâpamâcik itêwak otôkimâmiwâwa
sentences.english: And those young men, when they saw them come forth, “He comes with someone,” they said of their chief.”
“Why, surely, it is a woman!” they said.
When they had come near, they recognized that woman.

sentences.original: êwakw âwa kayâs ka-wâh-wanihiht itah kâ-miskawât! itêwak.
sentences.english: “It is that person who has been lost for this long time, whom now he has found here!” they said of her.
When they arrived there, yes, it was none other than the woman who had been lost!
“Truly, you have made a good find in a far-away place, Brother!”

sentences.original: êhag, kêswân nimiskawâw êyak oma kâ-sakâk, êh-itwêt, hâ, nikwêmê, tâpwê kimiyopayin! itêw.
sentences.english: “Yes, by chance I found her in this grove,” he said, and, “Ha, Brother, truly, you are fortunate!” he answered him.
Thereupon they went from that place.

sentences.original: itah êh-kapêsicik, ômis îtwêw : â, nisimitik, êkâ wiya kêkway kit-âtoskâtam aw îskwêw.
sentences.english: Where they encamped, he said, “Now, Brothers, this woman is by no means to work at anything.
It is you who will provide for her,” he told them.

sentences.original: hâ, tâpwê nama wiya tit-âtoskêw! itwêwak, ôh îskwêwa.
sentences.english: “Very well, she shall not do any work!” they said, of this woman.

sentences.original: êkosi miyêw ôma mihkwêkin, kaskikwâtah, kit-ôskotâkayin, êh-itêt, mîna kit-ôtâsiyin ôma, itêw ôh îskwêwa.
sentences.text: êkosi miyêw ôma mihkwêkin ê-itât itêw ôhi iskwêwa
sentences.english: Then he gave her that red cloth, saying to her, “Sew it for your skirt and for your leggings.”
Accordingly that woman sewed clothes for herself.
Truly, excellent were her clothes.
So now their number was thirty-one.

sentences.original: tâpwê êh-wâpaniyik, ê-sipwêhtêcik, namoya wâhyaw êy-ihtâcik, mostoswah wâpamêwak.
sentences.text: tâpwê ê-wâpaniyik ê-sipwêhtêcik namôya wâhyaw ê-ihtâcik mostoswa wâpamêwak
sentences.english: The next day, when they set out, they had not gone far, when they saw some buffalo.
Then, “Make a killing!” he told the others;
he told his followers to prepare food there for their journey.
They killed some of the game.
Then they pitched camp there.

sentences.original: êh-wâpahk, ê-sipwêhtêcik, kâ-pêhtahk êh-mah-matwêwêyik; mâka namoya kiskêyihtam tântêh kâ-matwêwêyik.
sentences.text: ê-wâpahk ê-sipwêhtêcik kâ-pêhtahk ê-ma-matwêwêyik mâka namôya kiskêyihtam tânitê kâ-matwêwêyik
sentences.english: On the next day, as they set out, he heard some shots; but he did not know whence the noise came.
They kept on walking and came to a river.
They saw some buffalo.
“Make a killing!” he told them;
“When you have killed some, we shall take the meat to the river.
There we shall camp.

sentences.original: kik-ôsîhtânânaw nîmâwinah, pêskis êkotah ohci kit-ây-asawâpiyahk ôma kâh-mâh-matwêwêk.
sentences.english: We shall prepare a store of meat, and at the same time reconnoitre from there as to that shooting.
Perhaps it was Blackfoot,” he told his followers.

sentences.original: êkosi sipwêhtêwak nîso oskinîkiwak, ê-wîh-kakwê-nipahâcik ôhi mostoswah.
sentences.text: êkosi sipwêhtêwak nîso oskinîkiwak ê-wî-kakwê-nipahâcik ôhi mostoswa
sentences.english: Then two young men went off to try to kill some of those buffalo.
They fired twice at them; they killed two.
When they saw that the young men had killed them, they went there.

sentences.original: êh-otihtâcik, hâw, mitoni kahkiyaw kakwê-otinamohkêk wiyâs.
sentences.english: When they got to them, “Now then, try to take every bit of the meat.

sentences.original: ôma sîpîhk kâ-sakâk, êkotah ka-kapêsinânaw, ta-nîmâwinihkêyêk, itwêw;
sentences.english: In that wooded spot by the river we shall camp, and there you will prepare the meat,” he said;
“We others will go on ahead.”
So then those young men skinned and cut up the carcasses.

sentences.original: êkwah ôki sîpîhk ôki kâ-takohtêcik, êkotah nakîwak, êh-otinakik mistikwah, êy-osîhtâcik wîkiwâwa.
sentences.text: êkwa ôki sîpîhk ôki kâ-takohtêcik êkota nakîwak ê-otinakik mistikwa ê-osîhtâcik wîkiwâwa
sentences.english: And those who went to the river, stopped there and gathered sticks and set up their tents.

sentences.original: nîso osîhtâwak, nîpiyah ohci êh-apahkwêcik wîkiwâwa.
sentences.text: nîso osîhtâwak nîpiya ohci ê-apahkwêcik wîkiwâwa
sentences.english: They built two, covering them with leaves.
And those young men brought in the meats.

sentences.original: êkwah âsay wâpamikwak kotakah ayîsiyiniwah, ôhi kâ-kîh-pêhtahkik êh-tasinamiyit, êwakoni kâ-wâpamikocik.
sentences.text: êkwa âsay wâpamikwak kotaka ayîsiyiniwa ôhi kâ-kî-pêhtahkik ê-tasinamiyit êwakoni kâ-wâpamikocik
sentences.english: Now, by this time they had been seen by the other people; those whom they had heard firing, by, them they had been seen.
When they were seen by the others, “Blackfoot!” these people, their fellow-tribesmen, thought of them.
Accordingly the others hid from them, while they prepared their dried meats.
At last it grow dark.
Then those others, who were many in number, went toward them.
At last they went to sleep.

sentences.original: êkwah ôki cîki âsay ayâwak, êh-nipâyit otôtêmiwâwa.
sentences.text: êkwa ôki cîki âsay ayâwak ê-nipâyit otôtêmiwâwa
sentences.english: By this time these people had come close to where their fellow-tribesmen were sleeping.
At last they reached them, as they slept.
They did not recognize them.

sentences.original: êkos îsi ôh owîkiyiwa ê-wîhkwêkâpawicik, êh-pâskiswâcik.
sentences.text: êkosi isi ôhi wîkiyiwa ê-wîhkwêkâpawicik ê-pâskiswâcik
sentences.english: And so they surrounded their tents and opened fire on them.

sentences.original: êh-pîkiskwêcik, ôki kâ-nipâcik, pêyak kâ-pêhtahk otôtêmiwâwa êh-pîkiskwêyit, kâ-têpwêt, niyanân! êh-itwêt.
sentences.text: ê-pîkiskwêcik ôki kâ-nipâcik pêyak kâ-pêhtahk otôtêmiwâwa ê-pîkiskwêyit kâ-têpwêt ê-itwêt
sentences.english: When they spoke, one of those who were sleeping there, heard that it was their fellow-tribesmen speaking, and shouted, saying, “It is we!”
sentences.footnote: LB on {}:  Note the exclusive first person plural.

sentences.original: pêyak ê-wîh-wayawiyâmot, otihtinik pêyak, êh-tahkamikot môhkomân ohci.
sentences.text: pêyak ê-wî-wayawiyâmot otihtinik pêyak ê-tahkamikot môhkomân ohci
sentences.english: When one of them fled out from a tent, one of the others seized him and stabbed him with a knife.
Only then did they hear and learn that by mistake they were firing on their own tribesmen.
“Heavens and earth! Our fellow-tribesmen!” he cried.
Then they stopped.
They had killed nearly all of them.

sentences.original: mitâtaht piko namoya nipahâwak; mâka kahkiyaw miswâwak.
sentences.text: mitâtaht piko namôya nipahâwak mâka kahkiyaw miswâwak
sentences.english: Only ten were not killed; but all were wounded.
Then, when they made a fire, they recognized their fellow-tribesmen.

sentences.original: awa okimâw iskwêwa kâ-wîcêwât, nipahâw ôhi kik îskwêwa kâ-kîh-kwâsihtwâkêt.
sentences.text: awa okimâw iskwêwa kâ-wîcêwât nipahâw ôhi kiki iskwêwa kâ-kî-kwâsihtwâkêt
sentences.english: That chief who had the woman with him, had been killed, together with the woman he had abducted.
The one who had been stabbed did not die.

sentences.original: pîhtokahâw, kwayask êh-pimisimiht, mâskôc ta-nipiw, êh-itêyihtamoht.
sentences.english: He was taken into a tent and carefully laid down, for, “No doubt he will die,” his people thought.

sentences.original: êkosi ôki kotakak kâ-misohcik, nama wiya ta-kîh-nipiwak, êh-itêyimâcik êwakoni, ka-sipwêhtahânawak; ka-kîwânânaw, itwêwak, êh-pakwâtahkik otôtêmiwâwa mihcêt êh-nipahâcik.
sentences.text: êkosi ôki kotakak kâ-misohcik ê-itêyimâcik êwakoni itwêwak ê-pakwâtahkik otôtêmiwâwa mihcêt ê-nipahâcik
sentences.english: But as for those others who had been wounded by shots, thinking of them, “They are not likely to die,” they said, “We shall take them away with us; we shall return home,” for they were down-hearted at having killed so many of their tribesmen.

sentences.original: êkosi sêmâk nakatêwak, osâm êh-pakwâtahkik êh-tôtawâcik owâhkomâkaniwâwa, êh-kîwêcik.
sentences.text: êkosi sêmâk nakatêwak osâm ê-pakwâtahkik ê-tôtawâcik owâhkômâkaniwâwa ê-kîwêcik
sentences.english: So immediately they left the slain, too much depressed at what they had done to their fellow-tribesmen, and went home.

sentences.original: êkwah awa kâ-tahkamiht êkotah pimisin pîhcâyihk.
sentences.text: êkwa awa kâ-tahkamiht êkota pimisin pîhcâyihk
sentences.english: The one who had been stabbed lay there within.

sentences.original: niyânan pîhcâyihk êkotah itah kâ-pimisihk êkotah pimisiniyiwa ôh ôskinîkiwah êh-kîh-nipahimiht.
sentences.text: niyânan pîhcâyihk êkota ita kâ-pimisihk êkota pimisiniyiwa ôhi oskinîkiwa ê-kî-nipahimiht
sentences.english: Inside there where he lay, lay five of the young men who had been slain.
Because they thought of him, “In any case he too will die,” was why he had been abandoned.
At last dawn came, as he lay there.
He lay there all day.
He drank no water; he did not eat.
“No doubt I too shall die,” he thought.

sentences.original: mâka itah kâ-pimisihk, opâskisikan êkotah astêyiw, êkwah pîhcasinânisah, môsasiniyah êh-asiwatêyik, êkwah kaskitêw êh-asiwatêyik.
sentences.text: mâka ita kâ-pimisihk opâskisikan êkota astêyiw êkwa pîhcasinânisa môsasiniya ê-asiwatêyik êkwa kaskitêw ê-asiwatêyik
sentences.english: But where he lay, there was his gun, and his ammunition-bags, with bullets in them, and with powder.
At last it was almost night.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê kâh-pêhtahk kêkway, êh-pa-pimisihk, êh-matwê-pê-pimohtêyit awiya.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê kâ-pêhtahk kêkway ê-pa-pimisihk ê-matwê-pê-pimohtêyit awiya
sentences.english: Presently he heard something, as he lay there, the sound of someone walking hither.

sentences.original: mâskôc wîstah pêyak apisîs êh-pimâtisit, itêyihtam, ôtah kotakihk mîkiwâhpihk, itêyihtam.
sentences.english: “Perhaps someone else who has a bit of life left in him,” he thought; “there in the other tent,” he thought.
When the other pushed his head into the doorway, and he looked at him, there was a bear looking at him.

sentences.original: êkos êcikây ani kê-nipahit, mayôwês nipiwakih! itêyihtam.
sentences.english: “And so this creature will kill me if I do not die soon enough for him!” he thought.
sentences.footnote: LB:  Literally, “he will kill me before I die with relation to him.”  Intransitive verbs have a set of forms which related the action (without making transitive) to a third person; the English

sentences.english: Finally it came into the tent.

sentences.original: êkotê skwâhtêmihk isi êh-pimisiniyit ôh ôskinîkiwa kâ-wayawîhtahât awa wâkayôs, ôh ôskinîkiwa êh-ntawi-môwât ohpimê, ômis îtêyihtam awa : nistah nika-môwik! itêyihtam.
sentences.text: êkotê iskwâhtêmihk isi ê-pimisiniyit ôhi oskinîkiwa kâ-wayawîhtahât awa wâkayôs ôhi oskinîkiwa ê-nitawi-môwât ohpimê ômisi itêyihtam awa itêyihtam
sentences.english: When the bear had taken out of the tent the young man who lay nearest the doorway, going off somewhere to eat him, then he thought, “He will eat me too!”
At last night came.
The young man could not sleep.
Finally day broke; he had not slept.

sentences.original: mitoni êh-kîsikâyik, âsay mîna kâ-pê-takohtêyit ôhi wâkayôsa;
sentences.text: mitoni ê-kîsikâyik âsay mîna kâ-pê-takohtêyit ôhi wâkayôsa
sentences.english: When it was full day, again there came the bear;

sentences.original: âsay mîna pê-paspiskwêyiyiwa, êh-kitâpamikot, wîst êh-kitâpamât.
sentences.text: âsay mîna pê-paspiskwêyiyiwa ê-kitâpamikot wîsta ê-kitâpamât
sentences.english: again it stuck its head into the doorway and looked at him, and he, in turn, looked at it.

sentences.original: ayisk namoya kîh-waskawîw, mistah ê-wîsakêyihtahk ôm îtah kâ-tahkamiht.
sentences.text: ayisk namôya kî-waskawîw mistahi ê-wîsakêyihtahk ôma ita kâ-tahkamiht
sentences.english: For he could not move, what with the great pain of his knife-wound.

sentences.original: itêh isi êy-isi-sâwahtôt, êkotê nîso pimisiniyiwa oskinîkiwa;
sentences.text: itê isi ê-isi-sâwahtot êkotê nîso pimisiniyiwa oskinîkiwa
sentences.english: Near his feet lay two young men;

sentences.original: êwakonih mîna pêyak kâ-wayawîtâpêyit ôhih wâkayôsah, aspin mîn êwakoni êh-ntawi-môwâyit.
sentences.text: êwakoni mîna pêyak kâ-wayawîtâpêyit ôhi wâkayôsa aspin mîna êwakoni ê-nitawi-môwâyit
sentences.english: one of these, again, the bear dragged out of the tent, and went away to eat him.

sentences.original: êkos êcik âni kahkiyaw kê-kitamokoyâhk itêyihtam êwako.
sentences.english: “And so it turns out that it will eat us all up!” thought he.
All day he lay there.

sentences.original: kêyâpic namoya minihkwêw; mîna namoya mîcisôw wiya.
sentences.text: kêyâpic namôya minihkwêw mîna namôya mîcisôw wiya
sentences.english: Again he did not drink; and he did not eat.

sentences.original: nama kêkway wâpahtam ta-mîcit; cikêmâ ôhi kâ-nipahikocik, êwakonik êh-manêsicik mîciwin, kahkiyaw otinamwak ôhi kâ-kîh-nîmâwinihkêyit; êkosi kâ-kîwêcik wiy êwakonik.
sentences.text: nama kêkway wâpahtam ta-mîcit cikêmâ ôhi kâ-nipahikocik êwakonik ê-manêsicik mîciwin kahkiyaw otinamwak ôhi kâ-kî-nîmâwinihkêyit êkosi kâ-kîwêcik wiya êwakonik
sentences.english: He saw nothing to eat; for, indeed, they who had killed them, being in want of food, had taken all the provisions which the others had prepared; and so they had gone home.

sentences.original: êkwah awa aspin kâ-wayawîhtahât oskinîkiwah, piyisk kapê-kîsik nama kêkway wîhkâc môsihtâw awa miswâkan.
sentences.text: êkwa awa aspin kâ-wayawîhtahât oskinîkiwa piyisk kapê-kîsik nama kêkway wîhkâc môsihtâw awa miswâkan
sentences.english: After that creature had taken that youth out of the tent, the wounded man noticed nothing more all day.

sentences.original: iyikohk êh-tipiskâyik, âsay mîna ka-pê-paspiskwêwiyit wâkayôsa, iyâyaw êh-kitâpamikot mâna, kinwêsk êh-kitâpamikot mâna, kâ-pê-pîhtokêyit.
sentences.text: iyikohk ê-tipiskâyik âsay mîna ka-pê-paspiskwêyiyit wâkayôsa iyâyaw ê-kitâpamikot mâna kinwêsk ê-kitâpamikot mâna kâ-pê-pîhtokêyit
sentences.english: When it was getting dark, again the bear came sticking its head under the door-flap, looking at him eagerly, as before; when, as before, it had looked at him a long time, it came into the tent.

sentences.original: kotakah mîn ôhi oskinîkiwa aspin mîna êh-wayawîhtahâyit, kêyâpic nîso pimisiniyiwa.
sentences.text: kotaka mîna ôhi oskinîkiwa aspin mîna ê-wayawîhtahâyit kêyâpic nîso pimisiniyiwa
sentences.english: When, again, it had taken out another of those youths, two still lay there.

sentences.original: âta wiya kêyâpic ôhi nîso ta-môwât, nama mayaw niya ta-môwit! têyihtam êwakô kapê-tipisk.
sentences.english: “I hope he will first eat these two, before he eats me!” he thought all that night.

sentences.original: êh-wâpaniyik, mitoni êh-kîsikâyik, âsay mîna kâ-pê-takohtêyit wâkayôsa, êkwah ôhi itêh kâ-pimisihk ôh ôskinîkiwa êykonih wayawîhtahêyiwa.
sentences.text: ê-wâpaniyik mitoni ê-kîsikâyik âsay mîna kâ-pê-takohtêyit wâkayôsa êkwa ôhi itê kâ-pimisihk ôhi oskinîkiwa êkoni wayawîhtahêyiwa
sentences.english: When day came, and it had grown quite light, again the bear arrived, and that youth who lay there, him it dragged out of the tent.

sentences.original: â, êkwah nêhi kâ-pimisiniyit, otâkosikih êyakoni ta-wayawîhtahêw, êkwah niya wâpahkih kîksêpâ kê-môwit! itêyihtam, ê-pa-pimisihk.
sentences.english: “Yes, now, in the evening, he will take out the one who lies over yonder, and tomorrow morning he will eat me!” he thought, as he lay there.
He had no energy.

sentences.original: êkwah mâskôc ahpôh nôhtaw nika-nipin! itêyihtam.
sentences.english: “But perhaps and as likely, I shall die before then!” he thought.
Thus he lay there all that day.
He still was unable to move.

sentences.original: piyisk êh-ati-ta-tipskâyik, âh, kêkâc êkwah mâna kâ-takohtêt wâkayôs! itêyihtam.
sentences.english: At last, as darkness approached, “Yes, and now it is near to the time when the bear always comes!” he thought.

sentences.original: mitoni iyikohk êh-tipiskâyik, êkoyikohk kâ-takohtêyit; mâka mîna êh-pê-paspiskwêyiyit, iyâyaw kitâpamik.
sentences.text: mitoni iyikohk ê-tipiskâyik êkoyikohk kâ-takohtêyit mâka mîna ê-pê-paspiskwêyiyit iyâyaw kitâpamik
sentences.english: When it had got quite dark, then it came; again it came sticking its head into the doorway, and eagerly looked at him.
When it had looked at him, it dragged out that young man, and off it went.

sentences.original: hâ, êkwah niya wâpahkih kê-nipahit, êkâ cêskwah nipiwakih! itêyihtam.
sentences.english: “Yes, and now tomorrow he will kill me, if I do not die before he comes!” he thought.

sentences.original: piyisk mistahi ati-ta-tipiskâyiw; mâka namoya kîh-waskâwîw, namoya ê-maskawâtisit.
sentences.text: piyisk mistahi ati-ta-tipiskâyiw mâka namôya kî-waskawîw namôya ê-maskawâtisit
sentences.english: At last it got darker and darker; he could not move; he had not strong life in him.
At last day began to come.

sentences.original: pîhtaw êcik âni êwako kê-kitimahit, mayawês nipiwakih ta-nipahit, ta-môwit! êh-itêyihtahk;
sentences.english: “And so now I must expect it; he will give me a painful death, killing me because I did not die for him in time, that he may eat me!” he thought;

sentences.original: kîkisêpâ pêy-itohtêci êkwah niya kê-nipahit! itêyihtam.
sentences.english: “When in the morning he comes, it is I this time whom he will kill!” he thought.
At last day grew bright.
He watched for it to come.
At last it was high day; the creature did not come.
When it was full noon, presently it came, breathing audibly.
“Now he will eat me!” he thought.

sentences.original: êh-pê-paspiskwêyiyit, âsay mîna kitâpamik; wistah ka-kitâpamêw.
sentences.text: ê-pê-paspiskwêyiyit âsay mîna kitâpamik wîsta ka-kitâpamêw
sentences.english: When it thrust its head into the doorway, again it looked at him; he, too, kept looking at it.
For a long time it gazed at him; at last it came inside.

sentences.original: â, êkwah niya kê-wayawîhtahit itêyihtam, kêyiwêhk êh-kostât, âtah namoya ê-maskawâtisit.
sentences.text: itêyihtam kêyiwêhk ê-kostât âta namôya ê-maskawâtisit
sentences.english: “Yes, now he will take me out with him!” he thought, fearing it, even though there was but little life in him.

sentences.original: pôti akâmâyihk nêtê kâ-pimohtêyit, itêh êh-itiskwêsihk, êkotah kâ-nîpawiyit.
sentences.text: pôti akâmâyihk nêtê kâ-pimohtêyit itê ê-itiskwêsihk êkota kâ-nîpawiyit
sentences.english: But it walked along the far side of the tent, and stood in the direction of his head, as he lay.
He was not able to move.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê êkotah kâ-nahapiyit, ocihciyah ômisi êh-itastât wâkayôs, êkotah ê-aspiskwêsimot, êh-apit, âskaw êh-kitâpamât ôh ôskinîkiwa.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê êkota kâ-nahapiyit ocihciya ômisi ê-itastât wâkayôs êkota ê-aspiskwêsimot ê-apit âskaw ê-kitâpamât ôhi oskinîkiwa
sentences.english: Presently the bear sat down there, placing its fore paws like this, and leaning its head on them, as it sat there, gazing at that young man.

sentences.original: êh-pôn-âpihtâ-kîsikâyik, kîtahtawê tâpiskôc êh-ati-miywamahcihot k-êtêyihtahk aw ôskinîkiw.
sentences.text: ê-pôn-âpihtâwi-kîsikâyik kîtahtawê tâpiskôc ê-ati-miywamahcihot kâ-itêyihtahk awa oskinîkiw
sentences.english: When the day was past noon, then at one time it seemed to that young  man as if he were feeling better and better.
“Dear me! Perhaps this creature means to take pity on me,”  he thought.

sentences.original: êkosi, namoya êtokw âwa! itêyihtam aw oskinîkiw, êh-pa-pimisihk.
sentences.english: And so, “Perhaps not he!” thought the youth, as he  lay there.
Towards nightfall, the bear arose.

sentences.original: hyâh! ê-wîh-môwit êkwah itêyihtam aw ôskinîkiw.
sentences.english: “Yah! Now he will eat me!” thought the youth.
It stretched itself, and went out of the tent.
It did not come in again just then.

sentences.original: hâw, mâskôc pîhtokêci, êkwah nika-môwik! itêyihtam.
sentences.english: “Yes, no doubt when he comes in, then he will eat me!” thought he.
Presently it came into the tent; it sat down in the same place as before.

sentences.original: êkosi, âh, namoya ês ân êtokê niwîh-nipahik! itêyihtam.
sentences.english: Then, “Why, it really does not seem that he is going to kill me!” he thought.
Then presently he felt as if he needed to sleep.

sentences.original: pôtih kâh-waskawît êkwah aw oskinîkiw, êh-akanahisot, êkwêyâk êh-waskawît, aspin kâh-nakatiht, niyânanwâw êh-tipiskâyik.
sentences.text: pôti kâ-waskawît êkwa awa oskinîkiw ê-akwanahisot êkwêyâk ê-waskawît aspin kâ-nakatiht niyânanwâw ê-tipiskâyik
sentences.english: And then that young man moved, putting the cover over himself; it was the first time he had moved, from the time he had been abandoned, for five days and nights.
And so he dozed for a little while.

sentences.original: piyis êh-pêkopayit, âsay kâ-wîh-wâpaniyik, tâpiskôc êh-miyomahcihot itêyihtam.
sentences.text: piyis ê-pêkopayit âsay kâ-wî-wâpaniyik tâpiskôc ê-miyomahcihot itêyihtam
sentences.english: Then, when he woke up, it had already dawned, and he felt quite well.
At last it was full daylight.
When high day had come, presently the bear rose to its feet and went out.
When it came back in, again it sat down there.
When he looked at it, it spoke to him as follows, speaking like a man: “'I am dying,' you think.
You shall not by any chance die,” it said to him.
“Alas, I wonder if he speaks true?” he thought.
“Yes, you will live,” it told him.
“Perhaps only to die of starvation,” he thought.

sentences.original: êkosi êkotah pa-pimisin; mitoni êkwah wâh-waskawîw ospitonah oskâtah mina.
sentences.text: êkosi êkota pa-pimisin mitoni êkwa wâh-waskawîw ospitona oskâta mîna
sentences.english: So he lay there; but now he kept moving his arms and logs quite freely.
But he was very tired;

sentences.original: osâm kinwêsk êh-pimisihk, êyak ohci k-ôh-nêstosit, êkwah mîna mistahi ê-kî-wîsakêyihtahk, mâka ati-miywamahcihôw, ôm êh-itikot ôhi wâkayôsah.
sentences.text: osâm kinwêsk ê-pimisihk êwako ohci kâ-ôh-nêstosit êkwa mîna mistahi ê-kî-wîsakêyihtahk mâka ati-miywamahcihôw ôma ê-itikot ôhi wâkayôsa
sentences.english: he was tired because he had lain so long, and also because he had suffered so much pain. But he felt better and better, now that that bear had said this to him.

sentences.original: kapê-kîsik êkotah êh-apiyit, êh-otâkosiniyik, kêkâc êh-tipiskâyik, kâh-nôhtê-waniskât.
sentences.text: kapê-kîsik êkota ê-apiyit ê-otâkosiniyik kêkâc ê-tipiskâyik kâ-nôhtê-waniskât
sentences.english: When it had sat there all day, toward evening, when darkness had almost fallen, he felt a desire to get up.
He raised himself and sat  up.
When he sat up, the bear rose to its feet and went out of the tent.

sentences.original: êyikohk mistah êh-tipiskâyik, pîhtokêyiwa, kêyâpic êkotah ê-nahapiyit.
sentences.text: iyikohk mistahi ê-tipiskâyik pîhtokêyiwa kêyâpic êkota ê-nahapiyit
sentences.english: When darkness had come, it entered and sat down again.
When it had sat down, he began to feel sleepy and to long for sleep.
So he lay down.
As soon as he lay down, he went to sleep.
He did not wake up again.
When he woke up, it was already high day.
He raised himself and sat up.
“And so I am going to live, after all!” he thought.
Then presently he took his ammunition-bags, meaning to go away.
“I wonder if I shall be able to get up on my feet?” he thought.

sentences.original: ê-kîh-otinahk opîhtasinânisah, êkwah pakwahtêhôw, ôma oskotâkay, wâpowâyân êy-oskotâkât.
sentences.text: ê-kî-otinahk opîhtasinânisa êkwa pakwahtêhôw ôma oskotâkay wâpowayân ê-oskotâkât
sentences.english: When he had taken his ammunition-bags, he fastened his belt round his coat, which was a blanket-robe.

sentences.original: êkwah sêkwasôw opîhtasinânisah; êkwah omaskisinah otinam, êyakonih mîna ê-sâ-sêkwasot.
sentences.text: êkwa sêkwasôw opîhtasinânisa êkwa omaskisina otinam êwakoni mîna ê-sâ-sêkwasot
sentences.english: He fastened the ammunition-bags under his belt; then he took his moccasins, fastening them, too, under his belt.
He took his gun.

sentences.original: ê-kîh-otinahk opâskisikan, kâ-pasikôyit ôhi wâkayôsah, êh-pêh-âhci-tahkoskêyit.
sentences.text: ê-kî-otinahk opâskisikan kâ-pasikôyit ôhi wâkayôsa ê-pê-âhci-tahkoskêyit
sentences.english: When he had taken his  gun, the bear rose to its feet and took a few steps toward him.
He was afraid of it.

sentences.original: kisiwâk êh-nîpawiyit, êh-kitâpamikot, âh, isk âwa ta-pasikôwak! itêyihtam.
sentences.english: When it stood close and looked at him, “Well, it seems I am to get up for him!” he thought.
When he tried to get on his feet, he was unable.

sentences.original: nicawâc ômis îsi wâwikaniyihk micimîw, êh-pasikôt.
sentences.text: nicawâc ômisi isi wâwikaniyihk micimîw ê-pasikôt
sentences.english: He needs held fast to the bear's back, as he rose to his feet.

sentences.original: êh-nîpawit, konta na-nampayiw, osâm kinwêsk êh-pimisihk.
sentences.text: ê-nîpawit konita na-namipayiw osâm kinwêsk ê-pimisihk
sentences.english: When he stood up, he reeled this way and that, because he had lain so long.

sentences.original: êkosi âhci tâhkoskêyiwa; wîstah âhci tahkoskêw, êh-micimît ôhi wâkayôsah wâwikaniyihk.
sentences.text: êkosi âhci tahkoskêyiwa wîsta âhci tahkoskêw ê-micimît ôhi wâkayôsa wâwikaniyihk
sentences.english: Then the bear took a step; he too took a step, holding fast to the bear's back.

sentences.original: namoy êkwah kostêw, mâskôc niwîh-pimâcihik, êh-itêyihtahk.
sentences.english: He did not fear it now, thinking, “Perhaps he means to help me to live.”
At last it led him out of the tent, and he started off.

sentences.original: nânitaw nêmitanaw tahkoskêwin êtokê êh-itohtêt, nêstosiw.
sentences.text: nânitaw nêmitanaw tahkoskêwin êtokê ê-itohtêt nêstosiw
sentences.english: When he had walked about forty steps, he was tired.
So he stood still.
The bear stood there a while.
It did not start off at once.

sentences.original: iyikohk wiya êh-itêyihtahk êh-âhcikâpawit, êkoyikohk kâ-wî-sipwêhtêyit.
sentences.text: iyikohk wiya ê-itêyihtahk ê-âhcikâpawit êkoyikohk kâ-wî-sipwêhtêyit
sentences.english: Only when he decided to move ahead from where he stood, only then did it move on.
He managed to go ahead.

sentences.original: mîna namoya wâhyaw itohtêw, âsay mîna êh-nêstosit.
sentences.text: mîna namôya wâhyaw itohtêw âsay mîna ê-nêstosit
sentences.english: Again he had not walked far, when he was tired.
Here too he stood for a long time, looking this way and that.
By this time it was afternoon.

sentences.original: piyisk êh-ah-âhtohtêcik, iyikohk êh-otihtahkik ôm îtah ka-kîh-pê-pinasiwêcik, âsay pahkisimoyiwa, ê-wîh-tipiskâyik.
sentences.text: piyisk ê-ay-âhtohtêcik iyikohk ê-otihtahkik ôma ita kâ-kî-pê-pinasiwêcik âsay pahkisimoyiwa ê-wî-tipiskâyik
sentences.english: At last, as they kept walking a little ways at a time, when they reached the spot where they had come down the bank on their way hither, the sun had  already set, and darkness was at hand.

sentences.original: itah êh-pasahcâyik, êkotah êh-at-îtohtêcik, mistahi nêstosiw, pîhtaw êh-nôhtêhkatêt mîna êh-nôhtêyâpâkwêt.
sentences.text: ita ê-pasahcâyik êkota ê-ati-itohtêcik mistahi nêstosiw pîhtaw ê-nôhtêhkatêt mîna ê-nôhtêyâpâkwêt
sentences.english: From their walk along the river-bottom he had become very tired, and now he was hungry and thirsty besides.
By the time it was entirely dark, they had almost  climbed to the top of the bluff.
When he stood still, the bear halted.
At last it sat down.
He too sat down there.
As soon as he had got himself into a comfortable position, it rose to its feet and walked off to one side.
At that moment he felt sleepy.
“Now I had better sleep,” he thought.
He lay down there.
At daybreak he awoke.
When daylight had come, presently he saw the bear walking toward him.
It came up to him; it sat down close by him.
By this time he was very thirsty.

sentences.original: êkwah kâ-pasikôt, êh-nêstohtêt, êkwah êkâ êh-ksiskâhtêt, mâskôc têhtapiyân nkâh-ksiskâhtân, itêyihtam.
sentences.text: êkwa kâ-pasikôt ê-nêstohtêt êkwa êkâ ê-kisiskâhtêt itêyihtam
sentences.english: When he had risen to his feet, as from weariness he could not walk well or fast, “Perhaps if I ride I shall go faster,” he thought.

sentences.original: êh-apiyit êkwah ômis îsi pâsitâhkoskêw, êh-nîpawit.
sentences.text: ê-apiyit êkwa ômisi isi pâsitâhkoskêw ê-nîpawit
sentences.english: Where the bear sat, he stepped straddling it, like this, as he stood.

sentences.original: kâ-pasikôyit, nisihkâc êkosi êkwah miyw-apiw, êh-têhtapit.
sentences.text: kâ-pasikôyit nisihkâc êkosi êkwa miyo-apiw ê-têhtapit
sentences.english: When it rose to its feet, he sank gently into a comfortable sitting position, riding on its back.

sentences.original: êkos îsi ê-sipwêhtêyit, êh-at-âmaciwêyit, êkw êh-ayîtâpit, êh-têhtapit ôhi wâkayôsa, êh-kîwêhtahikot, itê kâ-kîh-ohtohtêcik êkotêh, itêhkê êy-isi-kîwêhtahikot.
sentences.text: êkosi isi ê-sipwêhtêyit ê-ati-âmaciwêyit êkwa ê-ayîtâpit ê-têhtapit ôhi wâkayôsa ê-kîwêhtahikot itê kâ-kî-ohtohtêcik êkotê itêhkê ê-isi-kîwêhtahikot
sentences.english: And so it set out, climbing the rest of the bluff, he the while looking about him, as he rode the bear, which was taking him home, in the very direction from which he and his party had come.
When he had not gone far, he found water.

sentences.original: êkosi êkotah cîki nipîhk nahapiyiwa, êkwah êh-nîhtakosît, êh-minihkwêt, mina êh-kâsîhkwêt.
sentences.text: êkosi êkota cîki nipîhk nahapiyiwa êkwa ê-nîhtakosît ê-minihkwêt mîna ê-kâsîhkwêt
sentences.english: Accordingly the bear stopped by the water, and he dismounted and drank and washed his face.
The bear, too, drank.
When it had carefully cleaned and arranged itself, it came back and sat down there.

sentences.original: âsay mîna têhtapiw; êkosi êsi-paskôt, ê-sipwêhtêt.
sentences.text: âsay mîna têhtapiw êkosi êsi-pasikôt ê-sipwêhtêt
sentences.english: Again he mounted it; then it arose and started off.

sentences.original: kêkâc mitoni miyw-ayâw; itêyihtam, êh-pa-pmohtêt, êh-têhtapit.
sentences.text: kêkâc mitoni miyo-ayâw itêyihtam ê-pa-pmohtêt ê-têhtapit
sentences.english: He was close to feeling very well, it seemed to him, as he went along on his mount.
All that day he went ahead.
When it grew dark, the bear stopped and sat down.
So then he dismounted, and sat down a little ways off.

sentences.original: hâw, ôtah nika-nipân, êh-itêyihtahk, pasikôyiwa, êh-ati-sipwêhtêyit.
sentences.english: “Well, I shall sleep here,” he thought, and at that the bear rose to its feet and went away.
So he lay down for the night and slept.

sentences.original: êyikohk êh-pêkopayit, pôtih sâsay kîsikâyiw, osâm kinwêsk êh-nipât, kiyipa kâ-wâpamât êh-pêc-âstamohtêyit, pê-takohtêyit.
sentences.text: iyikohk ê-pêkopayit pôti sâsay kîsikâyiw osâm kinwêsk ê-nipât kiyipa kâ-wâpamât ê-pêci-âstamohtêyit pê-takohtêyit
sentences.english: When he woke up, he saw that it was already day, for he had slept long; at once he saw the bear coming towards him; it came up to him.
“Perhaps now I shall be able to walk,” he thought.

sentences.original: mâka mistahi nôhtêhkatêw; êkwah mîna nôhtêyâpâkwêw.
sentences.text: mâka mistahi nôhtêhkatêw êkwa mîna nôhtêyâpâkwêw
sentences.english: But he was very hungry; and he was thirsty again.
When he rose to his feet and started to go on, the bear rose to its feet and headed him off, walking round in front of him.

sentences.original: isk âwa ta-têhtapiyân mîna! êh-itêyihtahk, ncawâc têhtapiw.
sentences.english: “It seems he wants me to ride him again!” he thought, and needs mounted.
Then the bear started off.
He had not gone far, when he saw some water.

sentences.original: êkosi êkotah tohtêyiwa, êkotah êh-nakiyit, êh-minihkwêt, min êh-minihkwêyit.
sentences.text: êkosi êkota itohtêyiwa êkota ê-nakiyit ê-minihkwêt mîna ê-minihkwêyit
sentences.english: It went there and halted, and he drank, and it drank, too.

sentences.original: êyikohk mîna êh-kîh-ka-kâsîhkwêt, âsay mîna pasikôw, ê-wîh-sipwêhtêt; êkotah mîna pê-nahikâpawiyiwa.
sentences.text: iyikohk mîna ê-kî-ka-kâsîhkwêt âsay mîna pasikôw ê-wî-sipwêhtêt êkota mîna pê-nahikâpawiyiwa
sentences.english: When he had washed his face, he rose to his feet to go on; again it came there and stood, ready for him.

sentences.original: ncawâc mîna têhtapiw, ê-sipwêhtêyit, êh-pa-pmi-têhtapit kapê-kîsik.
sentences.text: nicawâc mîna têhtapiw ê-sipwêhtêyit ê-pa-pimi-têhtapit kapê-kîsik
sentences.english: So he needs mounted again, and it set out, and all day he rode on.

sentences.original: piyis nîso-kîsikâw âsay êh-têhtapit, êh-otâkosiniyik, kâ-wâpamât mostoswah.
sentences.text: piyis nîso-kîsikâw âsay ê-têhtapit ê-otâkosiniyik kâ-wâpamât mostoswa
sentences.english: At last, when he had ridden two days, toward evening, he saw some buffalo.
“I shall try to make a killing,” he thought; “I am hungry,” he thought.

sentences.original: tâpwê nihtakosîw, êh-ati-sipwêhtêt; pôti kâ-nahapiyit ôhi wâkayôsah.
sentences.text: tâpwê nîhtakosîw ê-ati-sipwêhtêt pôti kâ-nahapiyit ôhi wâkayôsa
sentences.english: Accordingly he dismounted and went off; the bear, he saw, sat down.
He kept going ahead.
At last he got near the buffalo.
At last he took a shot at them; he killed one.
Oh, he was glad, thinking, “So now I shall eat!”
And so he skinned it and out it up.
While he was preparing it, the bear came up to him.
When he had finished his butchering, he made a fire and cooked his meal.

sentences.original: êyikohk êh-kîsisahk wiyâs, itah êh-miywâsiniyik asamêw ôhi wâkayôsah, wîst êh-mîcisot.
sentences.text: iyikohk ê-kîsisahk wiyâs ita ê-miywâsiniyik asamêw ôhi wâkayôsa wîsta ê-mîcisot
sentences.english: When he had cooked the meat done, he gave the best parts of it to the bear, and he too ate some.
When they had eaten, darkness was falling.
He was tired; he lay down.

sentences.original: iyikohk mistah ê-tipiskâyik, êkwah mîna kotakah wiyâsah kîsisam, ê-wîh-osîhtât ta-nîmât.
sentences.text: iyikohk mistahi ê-tipiskâyik êkwa mîna kotaka wiyâsa kîsisam ê-wî-osîhtât ta-nîmât
sentences.english: When night had come, he cooked some more meat, to make provision for his journey.
He cooked much of it.
By this time he felt the need of sleep; he lay down for the night.
He slept.

sentences.original: iyikohk êh-pêkopayit, âsay âkwâ-kîsikâyiw, êkwah mîna ê-wîh-kakwê-mîcisot.
sentences.text: iyikohk ê-pêkopayit âsay âkwâ-kîsikâyiw êkwa mîna ê-wî-kakwê-mîcisot
sentences.english: When he awoke, it was already bright day, and again he felt like eating.
When he had eaten, he cooked some more meat.

sentences.original: iyikohk mistah êh-kîsikâk, êkoyikohk êtokê nika-sâkohtân ta-nayahtamân, êh-itêyihtahk, êkoyikohk ispi-kîsikâyiw.
sentences.text: iyikohk mistahi ê-kîsikâk ê-itêyihtahk êkoyikohk ispi-kîsikâyiw
sentences.english: When full daylight had come, “This much perhaps I shall be able to carry,” he thought; and by this time it was high day.
He made ready to go.

sentences.original: êh-nayahtahk onîmâwin, êh-wawêyît, êh-ati-sipwêhtêt, ah-âkwaskiskâk ôhi wâkayôsah, êh-ksâtamiyit wiyâsah.
sentences.text: ê-nayahtahk onîmâwin ê-wawêyît ê-ati-sipwêhtêt ay-âkwaskiskâk ôhi wâkayôsa ê-kisâtamiyit wiyâsa
sentences.english: When he took his provisions on his back, and got ready and was starting off, the bear kept getting in his way and keeping close to the meat.

sentences.original: piyisk ncawâc kâwih wayônîw, wiyâsah êw-otihtahk.
sentences.text: piyisk nicawâc kâwi wâyonîw wiyâsa ê-otihtahk
sentences.english: At last he was forced to turn back and go to where the meat was.

sentences.original: wiyâsah ôhi ê-sakâpîhkatahk, êkwah om askêkin êh-aciwisahk, êh-kîsi-mâh-manisahk, ôhi wâkayôsah têhtastâw owâwikaniyihk.
sentences.text: wiyâsa ôhi ê-sakâpîhkâtahk êkwa ôma askêkin ê-aciwisahk ê-kîsi-mâh-manisahk ôhi wâkayôsa têhtastâw wâwikaniyihk
sentences.english: He tied the meat up in a bundle, and cut the hide into small pieces, and when he had out off every bit, he placed it on the bear's back.

sentences.original: kwayask nîpawiw awa wâkayôs, êkwah êh-wîwahât ôhi wiyâsah.
sentences.text: kwayask nîpawiw awa wâkayôs êkwa ê-wîwahât ôhi wiyâsa
sentences.english: The bear stood still, while he loaded the meats on its back.

sentences.original: êyikohk êh-kîsi-wîwahât, êkwah êkosi êkwah êh-sipwêhtêt, êkwah êh-pimi-wîcêwât ôhi wâkayôsah, mistah ê-nayahtamiyit wiyâs.
sentences.text: iyikohk ê-kîsi-wîwahât êkwa êkosi êkwa ê-sipwêhtêt êkwa ê-pimi-wîcêwât ôhi wâkayôsa mistahi ê-nayahtamiyit wiyâs
sentences.english: When he had loaded it, then he started off, walking along with the bear, which was carrying a great load of meat.

sentences.original: itah êh-otihtahk nipiy, êkotah nihtinamwêw ôhi wiyâsah, êkotah êh-minihkwêt, ôtah nk-âyân; ôhi wiyâsah nka-pâsên, êh-itêyihtahk.
sentences.text: ita ê-otihtahk nipiy êkota nîhtinamawêw ôhi wiyâsa êkota ê-minihkwêt ê-itêyihtahk
sentences.english: Where he came to some water, there he took the meats from its back, and drank, thinking, “Here I shall stay; I shall dry these meats.”
He built a fire there, and prepared dried meat.
He stayed there all day, the bear keeping near him.
At last night came; he slept there.

sentences.original: êh-wâpaniyik, kapê-kîsik osîhtâw okâhkêwakoma, tahk êh-kotawêt, êh-pâsahk okâhkêwakoma, piyis kapê-kîsik.
sentences.text: ê-wâpaniyik kapê-kîsik osîhtâw okâhkêwakoma tahki ê-kotawêt ê-pâsahk okâhkêwakoma piyis kapê-kîsik
sentences.english: When morning came, all day he made his dried meat, building fires to dry his meats, until the day had passed.

sentences.original: êyikohk ê-tipiskâyik, êkoyikohk kîsihtâw okâhkêwakomah; êkoyikohk mîna tipiskâyiw.
sentences.text: iyikohk ê-tipiskâyik êkoyikohk kîsihtâw okâhkêwakoma êkoyikohk mîna tipiskâyiw
sentences.english: By nightfall he had finished his dried meats; by this time it was dark.
When he felt the need of sleep, he lay down.
When he awoke, day was dawning.

sentences.original: êkwah ma-mîcisôw; mîn âwa wâkayôs mîcisôw.
sentences.text: êkwa ma-mîcisôw mîna awa wâkayôs mîcisôw
sentences.english: Then he ate; the bear ate, too.
When they had eaten, he made ready to depart.

sentences.original: êkwah mîna nayahtahêw otêma wâkayôsa onîmâwina.
sentences.text: êkwa mîna nayahtahêw otêma wâkayôsa onîmâwina
sentences.english: Then again he loaded his provisions on the back of the bear, his animal of use.

sentences.original: êkosi êkwah êh-sipwêhtêt, êh-ati-wîcêwât ôhi wâkayôsa.
sentences.text: êkosi êkwa ê-sipwêhtêt ê-ati-wîcêwât ôhi wâkayôsa
sentences.english: So then he set out, the bear going with him.

sentences.original: êkwah sâsay êkwah miyw-ayâw ôma kâ-kîh-tahkamiht itah.
sentences.text: êkwa sâsay êkwa miyo-ayâw ôma kâ-kî-tahkamiht ita
sentences.english: By this time he had recovered from the wound where he had been stabbed.

sentences.original: ayis êwakonih ôhi wâkayôsah êh-wîcihikot, kiyipa k-ôh-miyw-ayât.
sentences.text: ayis êwakoni ôhi wâkayôsa ê-wîcihikot kiyipa kâ-ôh-miyo-ayât
sentences.english: Of course it was because that bear helped him that he got well so quickly.

sentences.original: êkosi om êkwah kâ-pa-pimohtêcik, kâh-kiyipah nakîw êh-mîcisot; osâm kinwêsk namoya kîh-mîcisôw.
sentences.text: êkosi ôma êkwa kâ-pa-pimohtêcik kâh-kiyipa nakîw ê-mîcisot osâm kinwêsk namôya kî-mîcisôw
sentences.english: Then, as they thus walked along, every little while he stopped and ate; he had gone too long without food.

sentences.original: êkwah mistah êh-kîh-wîsakêyihtahk, nawac kawâhkatisôw aw ôskinîkiw; êkwah êh-miyômahcihot, êyak ôhci kâh-kiyipa k-ôh-nôhtêhkatêt.
sentences.text: êkwa mistahi ê-kî-wîsakêyihtahk nawac kawâhkatosow awa oskinîkiw êkwa ê-miyomahcihot êwako ohci kâh-kiyipa kâ-ôh-nôhtêhkatêt
sentences.english: Also, because, he had suffered so much pain, that youth was badly worn down; so now, when he had got well, it caused him to get hungry at frequent intervals.

sentences.original: piyis tâpwê nisto-kîsikâw êh-pimohtêt, âsay namoya ayâw kâhkêwakwah.
sentences.text: piyis tâpwê nisto-kîsikâw ê-pimohtêt âsay namôya ayâw kâhkêwakwa
sentences.english: At last, when he had tramped three days, he had no more dried meats.

sentences.original: piyis wâpamêw êh-wîsakêyihtamiyit wâwikaniyiw ôhi wâkayôsah, osâm mistah ê-kîh-nayôhtamiyit kinwêsk kâhkêwakwah, êkwah wiya mîna ê-kîh-têhtapit kinwês; ayakô ohci k-ô-wîsakêyihtamiyit wâwikaniyiw.
sentences.text: piyis wâpamêw ê-wîsakêyihtamiyit wâwikaniyiw ôhi wâkayôsa osâm mistahi ê-kî-nayôhtamiyit kinwêsk kâhkêwakwa êkwa wiya mîna ê-kî-têhtapit kinwês êwako ohci kâ-ôh-wîsakêyihtamiyit wâwikaniyiw
sentences.english: He saw now that the bear was suffering in its back, from having carried so much dried meat for such a long time, and from his having ridden it so long; from all this its back was sore.

sentences.original: êkwah wiya pimiwitâw ôh ôkahkêwakoma, piyis mîna nîso-kîsikâw ê-nayahtahk kâhkêwakwah; namoya mâka mistahi âta wiyah êkwah kâ-pimiwitât.
sentences.text: êkwa wiya pimiwitâw ôhi okâhkêwakoma piyis mîna nîso-kîsikâw ê-nayahtahk kâhkêwakwa namôya mâka mistahi âta wiya êkwa kâ-pimiwitât
sentences.english: So then he carried his dried meats; he carried them on his back for two days; but there was not much for him to carry now.
Presently he came to a river.

sentences.original: êh-otâkosiniyik, ôma sîpiy êh-sâkêwêt, êkotah ê-sakâyik, êkotah kapêsiw.
sentences.text: ê-otâkosiniyik ôma sîpiy ê-sâkêwêt êkota ê-sakâyik êkota kapêsiw
sentences.english: Towards evening, when he came forth into sight of that river, there in a wooded place, he camped.

sentences.original: êkwah ê-kotawêt, ê-wîh-mîcisot, âsay ês ôma kotakah ayîsiyiniwah êh-wâpamikot; wiyah namoya wâpamêw.
sentences.text: êkwa ê-kotawêt ê-wî-mîcisot âsay êsa ôma kotaka ayîsiyiniwa ê-wâpamikot wiya namôya wâpamêw
sentences.english: Then, when he made a fire to prepare his meal, some people there saw him; but he did not see them.

sentences.original: êkosi ôma itah kâ-kotawêt, k-ây-apit, mêkwâc êh-mîcisot, kîtahtawê kâ-pasikôyit wâkayôsah, sîpîhk isi itêhkê êh-itâpiyit.
sentences.text: êkosi ôma ita kâ-kotawêt kâ-ay-apit mêkwâc ê-mîcisot kîtahtawê kâ-pasikôyit wâkayôsa sîpîhk isi itêhkê ê-itâpiyit
sentences.english: So then, when he had built a fire, and was sitting there eating, presently the bear got up and looked in the direction of the river.
“Why, he must have noticed something!” thought he.
He extinguished his fire.

sentences.original: ê-kih-âstawiyinahk, kîtahtawê kâ-simaciyit ôhô wâkayôsah, êh-itapiyit tahk êkotê, tâpiskôc kêkway êh-wâpahtamiyit; piyis pêy-itohtêyiwa itah k-âpit.
sentences.text: ê-kî-âstawinahk kîtahtawê kâ-simaciyit ôho wâkayôsa ê-itapiyit tahki êkotê tâpiskôc kêkway ê-wâpahtamiyit piyis pê-itohtêyiwa ita kâ-apit
sentences.english: When he had put it out, presently the bear got up on its hind legs and kept looking over there, as if it saw something; at last it came to where he sat.

sentences.original: tâpiskôc ê-wih-tapasiyit, itêyihtam, êh-kiti-kitâpamikot ôhi wâkayôsah.
sentences.text: tâpiskôc ê-wî-tapasiyit itêyihtam ê-kitâpamikot ôhi wâkayôsa
sentences.english: It seemed to him as if it wanted to flee, the way the bear kept looking at him.
sentences.footnote: LB on {êh-kiti-kitâpamikot}:  {-kiti-} is probably my error.

sentences.english: He  got up and went from that place.

sentences.original: sêmâk itah êh-pasahcâyik, êkotah at-îtohtêyiwa, mitoni ê-ksiskâhtêyit, tahkih sisonê sakâhk êh-at-itohtêyit.
sentences.text: sêmâk ita ê-pasahcâyik êkota ati-itohtêyiwa mitoni ê-kisiskâhtêyit tahki sisonê sakâhk ê-ati-itohtêyit
sentences.english: At once the bear made for the gully, walking very fast, keeping always along the edge of the woods.

sentences.original: piyis êh-otihtahk mistah ê-sakâyik, êkotah sêskisiyiwa.
sentences.text: piyis ê-otihtahk mistahi ê-sakâyik êkota sêskisiyiwa
sentences.english: At last, when it came to where the woods were dense, it went into the brush.

sentences.original: wistah sêskisiw; piyis itah êh-kaski-sakâyik, êkotah kâ-nahapiyit.
sentences.text: wîsta sêskisiw piyis ita ê-kaski-sakâyik êkota kâ-nahapiyit
sentences.english: He too went among the trees; finally, where the woods were densest, it sat down.
He sat down there, too.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê êkotê k-ôhtohtêcik tahki âh-itâpiyiwa ôhi wâkayôsah.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê êkotê kâ-ohtohtêcik tahki âh-itâpiyiwa ôhi wâkayôsa
sentences.english: Soon the bear began to look repeatedly in the direction whence they had come.
Presently he heard some people whistling.

sentences.original: miyâmay ayîsiyiniwak! êy-itêyihtahk, k-âti-samaskisiniyit ôhi wâkayôsah.
sentences.english: “Plainly, human beings!” he thought, as the bear lay close to the ground.
It seemed to him exactly as if the bear were frightened.
Then he slept there.
When it was full daylight, then he departed.
But he saw nothing.
So then he went on.
At last, when night came, he camped by the river.

sentences.original: êkwah êkotah êh-nipât, êh-wâpaniyik, êyikohk âsowaham ôma sîpiy.
sentences.text: êkwa êkota ê-nipât ê-wâpaniyik iyikohk âsowaham ôma sîpiy
sentences.english: There he slept, and on the next day, crossed the river.
He made the far side, in time.
By this time he was very well.

sentences.original: nistwâw êh-nipât, êkoyikohk kotak sîpiy otihtam.
sentences.text: nistwâw ê-nipât êkoyikohk kotak sîpiy otihtam
sentences.english: After three nights, he reached another river.

sentences.original: êkosi kisiwâk êkwah êkotah wâskahikan êh-ayâyik, wîstâwa êkotah êh-ayâyit, kihci-môhkomâna, wîstâwah êkotah êh-ayâyit, kihci-môhkomâna êh-owîstâwit, osîma êh-onâpêmiyit.
sentences.text: êkosi kisiwâk êkwa êkota wâskahikan ê-ayâyik wîstâwa êkota ê-ayâyit kihci-môhkomâna wîstâwa êkota ê-ayâyit kihci-môhkomâna ê-owîstâwit osîma ê-onâpêmiyit
sentences.english: Now close by this place was a trading-post, where his brother-in-law lived, an American, for he had an American, his younger sister's husband, as his brother-in-law.
sentences.footnote: LB on {kihci-môhkomâna}: No doubt Coming-Day meant to make him an American as a compliment to me; in the sequel he turns out to be a Frenchman.

sentences.original: êwako ohci, êh-kiskêyihtahk êwako, itah k-ôh-itohtêt, k-ôh-isi-kîwêt.
sentences.text: êwako ohci ê-kiskêyihtahk êwako ita kâ-ôh-itohtêt kâ-ôh-isi-kîwêt
sentences.english: For this reason, because he knew this, he had taken this way toward home.
They had already heard that those people had been killed.

sentences.original: aspin apisîs pimâtisiw; ê-kîh-itiht, itâcimostâmâwa owâhkomâkana.
sentences.english: “The last that was seen of him, he was scarcely alive; 'No doubt he will die,' was said of him,” was the story his relatives were told.
His sister, too, had heard it.

sentences.original: êkwah osîhtâw itah ê-wîh-pôsit, oma sîpiy ê-wîh-âsowahah.
sentences.text: êkwa osîhtâw ita ê-wî-pôsit ôma sîpiy ê-wî-âsowahahk
sentences.english: So now he made that on which to embark, so as to cross this river.
sentences.footnote: LB on {ê-wîh-pôsit}: Word avoidance: {mihtos} “raft”, freely used in Text 36.

sentences.original: êh-kîsihtât, êkwah êh-pôsit, êkwah êh-pimiskât, êh-âpasâpit, êkoyikohk tâwâyihk sîpîhk êh-ihtât, kâ-pê-pahkopêyit ôhi wâkayôsah.
sentences.text: ê-kîsihtât êkwa ê-pôsit êkwa ê-pimiskât ê-âpasâpit êkoyikohk tawâyihk sîpîhk ê-ihtât kâ-pê-pahkopêyit ôhi wâkayôsa
sentences.english: When he had finished it, and embarked, and paddled across, as he looked back, just as he was in the middle of the stream, into the water went the bear.
Close by where he landed, it came ashore.

sentences.original: âsay mâka nama kêkway ayâw ta-mîcit.
sentences.text: âsay mâka nama kêkway ayâw ta-mîcit
sentences.english: By this time again he had nothing to eat.

sentences.original: ayis ôhi wâkayôsah mâh-mistahi asamêw; êkô ohci k-ôh-kitâcik onîmâwiniwâwa.
sentences.text: ayis ôhi wâkayôsa mâh-mistahi asamêw êwako ohci kâ-ôh-kitâcik onîmâwiniwâwa
sentences.english: For he had always given the bear much to eat; that was how they had used up their supplies.
That place where they came ashore was an island.

sentences.original: êkosi êkotah tahkohcâyihk namoya wâhyaw k-âyâyit ôhi wîstâwa.
sentences.text: êkosi êkota tahkohcâyihk namôya wâhyaw kâ-ayâyit ôhi wîstâwa
sentences.english: And not far from there, at the top of the bank, was where his brother-in-law lived.

sentences.original: êkwah sakâhk êkotah apiw mîn awa wâkayôs.
sentences.text: êkwa sakâhk êkota apiw mîna awa wâkayôs
sentences.english: He stayed there in the woods, with the bear.
“How shall I manage to part from this creature?

sentences.original: mâskôc awa tit-âkâwâtik ôhi kihci-môhkomânah, itêyimêw, ta-nôhtê-nipahikot, itêyihtam.
sentences.english: Most likely this American will want to eat him,” he thought of the bear; “He will want to kill him,” he thought.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê ômisi k-êtikot, êkwêyâk êh-kitotikot ôhi wâkayôsah,
sentences.text: kîtahtawê ômisi kâ-itikot êkwêyâk ê-kitotikot ôhi wâkayôsa
sentences.english: Presently it spoke thus to him, speaking to him only now:

sentences.original: hâ, nikwêmê, ê-kitimâkisiyan, ê-wîh-nipiyan, êh-itêyihtaman, êh-itêyimiyin, kitêyimitn, êh-itêyihtamân.
sentences.english: “Well, Brother, when you were in misery and were about to die, and 'Surely I shall die,' was your thought, and, 'Surely he will eat me,' was your thought concerning me, then, 'Suppose I try to make him live,' I thought about you, for, 'He is to be pitied,' I thought.
'If he lives, I shall stay with him, when he goes to his fellows,' I thought concerning you,” it said to him.
“Oh, Brother, I cannot do that!
These people, this Frenchman to whom I am going, will kill you.

sentences.original: êkwah mîna ntôtêmak otihtakwâwi, kîskwêwak oskinîkiwak; kika-nipahikwak.
sentences.english: And when I reach my  fellow-tribesmen, the young men are reckless; they will kill you.
It is unlikely that I can bring the young men to respect my wishes; they will kill you.
sentences.footnote: LB: In such a matter, the conduct to be expected of a white man is on a level with that of the most reckless Indian adolescent.

sentences.english: I do not want to have you with me when I arrive where the others are,” he told it.

sentences.original: â, namoya, nikwêmê! ohcitaw kiwîh-papâ-wîcêtin, itik.
sentences.english: “Oh, no, Brother! Even so, I want to go about with you,” it answered him.
“Well, Brother, stay here.
I am going to that Frenchman's.
I am hungry, you see.”
“I too am hungry,” it said.
“I shall keep that in mind!”
sentences.footnote: LB:  This word means that the speaker will conform with the wish you have expressed.

sentences.original: êkos âti-pasikôw, ê-nakatât ôhi wâkayôsah, êh-âsowahahk oma apisîs êh-nipîwisiyit; ministikohk ayisk kâ-nakatât.
sentences.text: êkosi ati-pasikôw ê-nakatât ôhi wâkayôsa ê-âsowahahk ôma apisîs ê-nipîwisiyit ministikohk ayisk kâ-nakatât
sentences.english: Then he arose, and left the bear, and crossed the bit of water that lay between; for it was on an island that he left the bear.
sentences.footnote: CHECK -siyit as an inanimate diminutive suffix on 'have water'

sentences.original: ê-kîs-âmaciwêt, kisiwâk ayisk k-âyâyik ôma wâskahikan, êkotah êh-itohtêt, cîk êh-ihtât, kâ-pê-wayawiyit ôhi wêmistikôsiwa.
sentences.text: ê-kîsi-âmaciwêt kisiwâk ayisk kâ-ayâyik ôma wâskahikan êkota ê-itohtêt cîki ê-ihtât kâ-pê-wayawiyit ôhi wêmistikôsiwa
sentences.english: When he had climbed the bank, he went to the house, for it was right by there. When he came near, that Frenchman came out.
When he saw him, he stood still and looked at him.
At last, when he had come closer, the other fully recognized him.
He went into the house;

sentences.original: kiyipah mîna pê-wayawiyiwa, osîmah asicih êh-pê-nakiskâkot, hây hây! êh-pê-itwêyit osîma, êh-atamiskâkot, wîstâwa osîmah mîna êh-itikot, kikîh-itikawin, itik wîstâwa.
sentences.text: kiyipa mîna pê-wayawiyiwa osîma asici ê-pê-nakiskâkot ê-pê-itwêyit osîma ê-atamiskâkot wîstâwa osîma mîna ê-itikot itik wîstâwa
sentences.english: at once he came out again, and he and his sister came to meet him, his sister crying, “Splendid!” as they greeted him, his brother-in-law and his sister both saying this to him. “'Long ago he was killed by his fellow-tribesmen,' they said of you,” his brother-in-law told him.
He laughed;

sentences.original: kiwâpamin ôma; namoya êh-nipahikawiyân, kâ-wâpamiyan, êh-itikot.
sentences.english: “You see me here; since you see me, it cannot be that I have been killed,” he told him.
sentences.footnote: LB on {êh-itikot}:  Obvious case of mixing up third person and obviative; narrator should have said {êh-itât}.

sentences.english: “Come, let us go indoors,” they said to him.
They went into the house.
“Sit there on the bedstead,” they told him;
“You must be tired,” they told him.

sentences.original: êkos êh-ati-paminawasoyit osîma, ta-miyo-mîcisot, êh-itêyimikot, êkwah wiya êh-âcimostawât wîstâwa ôh iyikohk êh-kwatakihtât, êh-itêyihtahk.
sentences.text: êkosi ê-ati-paminawasoyit osîma ta-miyo-mîcisot ê-itêyimikot êkwa wiya ê-âcimostawât wîstâwa ôhi iyikohk ê-kwatakihtât ê-itêyihtahk
sentences.english: Then his sister went on to cook, meaning that he should eat well, while he told his brother-in-law of his sufferings, as they seemed to him.
Then they ate.

sentences.original: êh-kîsi-mîcisocik, sêmak wâpowayân, pakiwânasâkay, ospwâkanah, ciscêmâsah, kocawâkanisah êh-miyikot wîstâwa, omatôwahk namoya ka-kîh-miyitin; namoya ka-miywêyimâw, êh-itikot;
sentences.text: ê-kîsi-mîcisocik sêmâk wâpowayân papakiwayânasâkay ospwâkana ciscêmâsa kocawâkanisa ê-miyikot wîstâwa ê-itikot
sentences.english: When, they had eaten, at once his brother-in-law gave him a blanket, a shirt, a pipe, tobacco, and matches, and said to him, “These things here I cannot give you; you would not like them;
sentences.footnote: LB on {omatôwahk}: Gesture to trousers; ordinarily one says {nitâs}: “my trousers”, {mitâs}: “trousers” etc.; but this primarily means the native legging-like breeches, aid in this passage a distinction between the two is desired.

sentences.english: your sister will sew something into leggings for you,” he told him.
“Very well,” he answered.

sentences.original: êkwah êkotah ay-ayâw, tahkih ê-miyo-mîcisot, tah k-ây-ayât.
sentences.text: êkwa êkota ay-ayâw tahki ê-miyo-mîcisot ita kâ-ay-ayâ-t
sentences.english: Then he stayed there, eating good food all the while he was there.

sentences.original: êh-kîkisêpâyâyik, wayawîhtatâw nanâtohk ê-wîhkicisiyit pahkwêsikanah, êh-ntaw-âsamât wâkayôsah, maywês waniskâyit wistâwa.
sentences.text: ê-kîkisêpâyâyik wayawîhtatâw nanâtohk ê-wîhkicisiyit pahkwêsikana ê-nitawi-asamât wâkayôsa maywês waniskâyit wîstâwa
sentences.english: Early in the morning, he took out of the house all kinds of tasty cakes, and went to feed the bear, before his brother-in-law had got up.
The bear, he found, was still there.

sentences.original: êkwah êh-kîwêt, êh-pîhtokêt, kiyipa waniskâyiwah êkwa wîstâwa.
sentences.text: êkwa ê-kîwêt ê-pîhtokêt kiyipa waniskâyiwa êkwa wîstâwa
sentences.english: When he went back, as he entered the house, soon his brother-in-law got up.

sentences.original: êh-wâpamikot, wa, tâpwê mistahi kitânawêw! itêyihtamiyiw.
sentences.english: When he saw him, “Why, really, he does consume a big amount of food!” was the other's thought.
So then he stayed there all day.

sentences.original: êkoyikohk mîna êh-tipiskâyik; âsay mîna wiyâkanihk mistahih astâyiwa mîciwin.
sentences.text: êkoyikohk mîna ê-tipiskâyik âsay mîna wiyâkanihk mistahi astâyiwa mîciwin
sentences.english: It grew dark; again the other put a great deal of food into a dish.

sentences.original: niyôhtêhkatêyini, ka-mîcisoyin; mitoni kisîhkacin, itik wîstâwa, osâm mistahih ê-pimohtêyan, êh-itikot.
sentences.english: “This is so that you may eat whenever you get hungry; you are too thin,” his brother-in-law said to him, “because you tramped so much,” he told him.

sentences.original: tâpwê êyikohk mîna êh-nipâyit, êkoyikohk wîsta nipâw.
sentences.text: tâpwê iyikohk mîna ê-nipâyit êkoyikohk wîsta nipâw
sentences.english: So then, when the others went to sleep, he too slept.
In the morning, when he awoke, “There, I shall go feed him,” he thought.

sentences.original: âsay mîna sipwêhtêw, êh-ntaw-âsamât, nam êskwa ê-waniskâyit wîstâwa, kêsiskaw mâna ê-ntaw-âsamât.
sentences.text: âsay mîna sipwêhtêw ê-nitawi-asamât nama êskwa ê-waniskâyit wîstâwa kêsiskaw mâna ê-nitawi-asamât
sentences.english: Again he went off to feed the bear; before his brother-in-law had got up, he went, this time as before, to feed it.

sentences.original: iyikohk ê-waniskâyit wîstâwa, tâpwê mistahi mîcisôw nîstâw!
sentences.english: When his brother-in-law got up, “Really, my brother-in-law eats a great deal!
What can he be doing?
Surely he can not eat all that:

sentences.original: mahtih nka-kanawêyimâw tânis âwa êh-tôtahk, êy-itêyimât wîstâwa.
sentences.english: Suppose I watch him to see what he does,” he thought concerning his brother-in-law.
Then he stayed there all day.

sentences.original: iyikohk mîna êh-tipiskâyik, ahâw, niwîkimâkan, mahtih mistahih astây êkwah mîciwin, kistês kâ-mîcit mânah.
sentences.english: When night had come again, “Now my wife, place a great deal of food for your brother to eat.
sentences.footnote: LB:  Literally, “Place in great amount the food which your brother always eats.”

sentences.original: mâskôc awa nânitaw êy-itâpacihtât, namoya êkoyikohk ta-kîh-kitât, iyikohk mâna k-âstêyikih.
sentences.english: It must be that he uses it for something or other; he could not possibly eat up as much as is always at his place.”
“Yes,” said the woman.

sentences.original: tâpwê ê-wîh-kawisimocik, mistiyâkanihk êkotôwihk êkwah astâw mîciwina, êkotah ê-ntawi-pakitinamwât itah mâna kâ-nipâyit ostêsah.
sentences.text: tâpwê ê-wî-kawisimocik mistiyâkanihk êkotowihk êkwa astâw mîciwina êkota ê-nitawi-pakitinamwât ita mâna kâ-nipâyit ostêsa
sentences.english: Accordingly, when they were about to go to bed, she put food into a huge dish and went and set it down for her brother where he always slept. ed, and then they all got up and went about their day's work.

sentences.original: piyis mistah ê-tipiskâyik, êkwah ê-kawisimocik, namoya wîh-nipâw awa wêmistikôsiw, êh-kanawêyimât wîstâwa.
sentences.text: piyis mistahi ê-tipiskâyik êkwa ê-kawisimocik namôya wî-nipâw awa wêmistikôsiw ê-kanawêyimât wîstâwa
sentences.english: Then, when it was deep night, and they had gone to bed, that Frenchman did not go to sleep, but watched his brother-in-law.
At last day broke.
Presently he heard his brother-in-law go out of the house.

sentences.original: êh-tawinahk, wapamonâpiskohk ohci kâ-wâpamât, êh-atimohtêyit, wiyâkan êh-tahkonamiyit, sîpîhk êh-itohtêyit, aspin êh-âkawêwêyit.
sentences.text: ê-tawinahk wâpamonâpiskohk ohci kâ-wâpamât ê-atimohtêyit wiyâkan ê-tahkonamiyit sîpîhk ê-itohtêyit aspin ê-âkawêwêyit
sentences.english: He opened the door, and with a mirror he saw him, as he went off holding the dish, and made for the river, disappearing round a bend.
He kept on the lookout for him.
It was quite a while before he came back into view.

sentences.original: iyikohk ê-pê-sâkêwêyit, pôtih nama kêkway mîciwin pêtâyiwa, nayêstaw wiyâkan.
sentences.text: iyikohk ê-pê-sâkêwêyit pôti nama kêkway mîciwin pêtâyiwa nayêstaw wiyâkan
sentences.english: When he came into view, there, he was bringing no food at all, only the empty bowl.

sentences.original: iyikohk êh-pîhtokêyit, êkoyikoh itohtêw, êkwah ê-kotawêt, êkwah ê-paminawasot, êkwah kahkiyaw waniskâwak, êkw êh-ây-atoskêcik.
sentences.text: iyikohk ê-pîhtokêyit êkoyikohk itohtêw êkwa ê-kotawêt êkwa ê-paminawasot êkwa kahkiyaw waniskâwak êkwa ê-âh-atoskêcik
sentences.english: When the other came in, he went there and built the fire and cooked, and then they all got up and went about their day's work.
Finally, “Suppose I go there.

sentences.original: tâns âwa tiyôtahk nîstâw ? itêyihtam, êh-itohtêt.
sentences.english: What can my brother-in-law be doing?” he thought, and went there.

sentences.original: pôtih sîpiy êh-otihtahk, ati-mitihtêw itah ê-mostâwahkâyik, wistâwa êh-pâ-pimohtêyit, piyis sakâhk.
sentences.text: pôti sîpiy ê-otihtahk ati-mitihtêw ita ê-mostâwahkâyik wîstâwa ê-pâ-pimohtêyit piyis sakâhk
sentences.english: When he came to the river, he followed the other's tracks on the bare sand, where his brother-in-law had walked, and then into the woods.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê k-ôtihtahk itah êsa mâna kâ-sîkihtitâyit ôhi mîciwina, kâ-mâtâhât wâkayôsah.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê kâ-otihtahk ita êsa mâna kâ-sîkihtitâyit ôhi mîciwina kâ-mâtâhât wâkayôsa
sentences.english: Presently he came to where, evidently, the other had been in the habit of pouring out that food, and there he found the tracks of a bear.
So then that Frenchman went back home.
“So it is a bear he has always gone off here to feed!” he thought.
When he got back, he told his wife.

sentences.original: ômis îtêw : ês âwa mâna mistahi k-âsamat kistês; ês âwa mâna wâkayôsah êh-ntaw-âsamât.
sentences.english: He said to her: “As to this great amount of food you have been giving your brother, it seems he has been going off to feed it to a bear.

sentences.original: nikîh-ntaw-ôtihtên itah mâna k-âsamât; mâka namoya niwâpamâw wâkayôs, itêw;
sentences.english: I have been down to the place where he feeds it; but I have not seen the bear,” he told her;

sentences.original: hâw, nawac êkwa mistahi astawâhkan wiyâkanihk, ta-kîspoyit wâkayôsah, itêw.
sentences.english: “So now, do you put a great deal into the bowl, that the bear may stuff itself,” he told her.
sentences.footnote: LB:  Perhaps with ill intent toward the bear.

sentences.english: “Yes,” she answered him.

sentences.original: êkosi aw îskwêw nêo êsinâkwaniyik papakiwânêkin nâh-nîso tipahikan êyikohk miyêw ostêsah.
sentences.text: êkosi awa iskwêw nêwo êsinâkwaniyik papakiwânêkin nâh-nîso tipahikan iyikohk miyêw ostêsa
sentences.english: Then that woman gave her elder brother four pieces of cotton cloth, all of the same pattern, of two yards each.

sentences.original: haw, kâ-nâh-ntaw-asamat ôma miyâhkan ôhi, itêw ostêsah;
sentences.english: “Now, give these to him you always go to feed,” she told her elder brother;
“And give him this to eat.
Your brother-in-law saw you when you went off to feed him,” she told her elder brother.
“Yes,” he said;
“It is because I was unwilling to bring him here.
It is owing to him that I live and that you see me,” he told his sister.
And really, he went to feed it, and, there, it had run away.

sentences.original: êkwah mitihtêw; itah êkos êh-paskwâyâyik, êkotah miskawêw.
sentences.text: êkwa mitihtêw ita êkosi ê-paskwâyâyik êkota miskawêw
sentences.english: Then he tracked it; there where the open country began, there he found it.

sentences.original: ômis itêw : âh, êyakw âni iskwêyâc êh-pê-asamitân, mîn ôh êh-miyitân.
sentences.english: He spoke to it as follows: “Now, this is the last time I am coming to feed you; and I am giving you these things.
Go away from this place.

sentences.original: êkwah kika-nipahik piyisk, êkâ wî-sipwêhtêyini, itêw.
sentences.english: He will kill you in the end, if you do not go away,” he told it.
“Very well,” it answered him;

sentences.original: â, nikwêmê, kâkikê kisîwâk ohci kika-kanawêyimitn.
sentences.english: “Now, Brother, for all time to come, from close by I shall be guarding you.
You will be a chief,” it told him;
“It seems that you are unwilling to have me go about with you,” it told him.
“Yes.”

sentences.original: êkwah kîwêw êkwah wîstâwah wîkiyihk wêmistikôsiwa.
sentences.text: êkwa kîwêw êkwa wîstâwa wîkiyihk wêmistikôsiwa
sentences.english: Then he went back to his brother-in-law, the Frenchman's house.
Then the bear went away from there.

sentences.original: êkwah êkotah wîstâwah wâskâhikanihk ayâw, mitonê êh-miyw-ayât.
sentences.text: êkwa êkota wîstâwa wâskahikanihk ayâw mitoni ê-miyo-ayât
sentences.english: And he stayed there in his brother-in-law's trading-post, and was very well.
Then he said to his brother-in-law, “I want to go home,” he told him.
“Very well.”

sentences.original: êkosi miyik misatimwa pêyak êkwah aspapiwin.
sentences.text: êkosi miyik misatimwa pêyak êkwa aspapiwin
sentences.english: Then the other gave him a horse and a saddle.

sentences.original: êkosi êkwah êh-wâpahk wawêyîw, kahkiyaw kêkway êkwah ayôwinisah êh-miyikot.
sentences.text: êkosi êkwa ê-wâpahk wawêyîw kahkiyaw kêkway êkwa ayiwinisa ê-miyikot
sentences.english: Then at day-break he got ready, and they gave him all kinds of useful things.
So then he set out, to go home.
When he had slept three times, he came in sight of the camp.

sentences.original: êkotah êh-takosihk, pôtih ôhtâwiyah okâwiyah êkotah ayâyiwa; wâpamêw.
sentences.text: êkota ê-takosihk pôti ôhtâwiya okâwiya êkota ayâyiwa wâpamêw
sentences.english: When he arrived, there were his father and mother; he saw them.
They were glad.
“Truly, very glad am I that my son is alive!
When it had been said, 'He was killed,' truly it is a joyful surprise to see my son!” he said to him.

sentences.original: kahkiyaw ayîsiyiniwah êh-atâmiskâkot, ê-miywêyihtamiyit êh-pimâtisit, êkosi êkotah ohci êkwah kihtêyihtâkosiw aw oskinîkiw.
sentences.text: kahkiyaw ayîsiyiniwa ê-atamiskâkot ê-miywêyihtamiyit ê-pimâtisit êkosi êkota ohci êkwa kihtêyihtâkosiw awa oskinîkiw
sentences.english: All the people greeted him and were glad that he was alive, and so, from that time on, they all thought a great deal of this young man.

sentences.original: êkosi tâpwê mwêstas iyikohk êsah kih-okimâwiw.
sentences.text: êkosi tâpwê mwêstas iyikohk êsa kî-okimâwiw
sentences.english: Accordingly it really turned out later that he became a chief.
And so this is the end of the story.
